SECTION VI - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



INTRODUCTION

     In 1990, the Congress of the United States amended the Clean Air Act (CAA) such that the

USEPA was mandated to promulgate a rule that required development of chemical accident

prevention/community right-to-know regulations for all public, commercial and/or industrial

facilities that store and/or use threshold quantities of toxic, hazardous or explosive chemicals.  In

response to the congressional mandate, EPA promulgated the Risk Management Program Rule

(RMP Rule).

     The RMP Rule identified covered facilities on the basis of use/storage of threshold quantities

of any of a long list of chemicals (see 40 CFR Part 68.130, Table 1) and required those facilities to

submit to EPA a completed RMP by June 21, 1999.  Further, the RMP Rule requires that all covered

facilities must review all aspects of their respective plans and re-submit to EPA RMP updates every

five years thereafter as long as a facility is covered by the Rule.



FINDINGS (as of June, 2004)

     A second compliance audit and a hazard review was completed in June, 2004 for the City of

Gretna's water treatment plant  as required by the RMP rule and the appropriate offsite consequence

assessment (OCA) modeling was re-visited  done as well.  No significant problems were noted by

those efforts.  The OCA continues to predict a very small impact area such that area

residents/occupants should have little to no concern relative to the subject facility.

     A dress rehearsal of the implementation of the Emergency Response Plan component of the

subject facility's RMP was held on June 18, 2004 to ensure that the first responders, e.g., local police

and fire department personnel were properly trained and coordinated for first response conditions

and circumstances
